Ashes of Immortality
Vampires vs Werewolves vs Hunters... Guess which group you're playing with? Find out in this exciting 16-bit style RPG full of twists and colorful characters!

About This Game

Description



Mankind lives in terror. The things that haunt our nightmares, that stalk the shadows, that go bump in the night... the things we tell ourselves could never be real, are more than real now.
They are everywhere. Creatures of the darkness plague the continent. This is Ruthven, a world where Hunters, Vampires and Werewolves fight to determine which species shall prevail. Can you make a difference in the balance?



What begins as a simple mission to free a small town from evil quickly turns into a quest of discovery and revelation, as Simona Rinoldt, a Hunter from the Family, must travel a dangerous world, making unlikely allies, and facing unbeatable foes.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP/Windows Vista/Windows 7/8
    • Processor: 1.6 GHz
    • Memory: 128 MB RAM
    • Graphics: DirectX 9.0 Compatible
    • DirectX: Version 9.0
    • Hard Drive: 100 MB available space
    • Sound Card: DirectX 9.0 Compatible Sound

17 of 22 people (77%) found this review helpful
cbtx
606 products in account
40 reviews
Recommended
8.9 hrs on record
Posted: July 1
With every 16-bit type rpg one of the most important elements is the story ---- the fundamental narrative to maintain interest, the pacing to avoid boredom, and the character development to add some fun are all very important, and all of these aspects are nicely tied together in "Ashes of Immortality".


The game is quick to start and the first dungeon of many is at hand, and the adventure begins as Simona (a hunter) travels throughout a large world inhabited by vampires of all types, werewolves, ghouls, and a host of other supernatural creatures. She will recruit allies along the way each of whom has their own story to explore as bonds are formed and personalities develop.


There are many battles along the way, but they never overpower the actual story, and the game does a good job of keeping your interest in what is going to happen next ---- and there are, indeed, lots of surprises.


Each area is nicely presented ---- towns, dungeons, woods, etc. ---- and all need to be carefully explored for the treasures to be found.


Music is nicely done, stays in the background yet adds to the structure of the game.


In addition to the main story, there are many side quests to do, all of which offer good rewards for completion.


All of the characters, including the npcs, are interesting, entertaining, and are easy to like ---- even the somewhat eccentric ones.


There are a great many things to like here, and I think anyone that enjoys the 16-bit type rpgs will have a great time with this well told tale.
Read More

Posted: July 5
If you like the classic rpg game, this was a pretty sweet game. I rather enjoyed the storyline and how it got all these different people to interact. It was a rather solid story with cool game play. THere was some lack of guiding, but it was a pretty awesome game, overall.

MakoSipper
2,489 products in account
83 reviews
Not Recommended
15.0 hrs on record
Posted: November 5
Ashes of Immortality is one of the most amateur games I've played in a loooong time. Basically, a generic RPG with no testing, lacking originality, and that seems to have been as rushed as it could.

Pros & Cons :

+ Can be a 8-10 hour distraction if you take it casually as a Solitaire game

- A lot of generic art and music that I recognize from other games, probably from RPGM packs
- Story is all over the place and tries too hard to rely just on featuring vampires
- Characters are very cliché and underdeveloped
- Battle is completely unbalanced, and you basically just attack, except on some bosses, and when the difficulty suddenly skyrockets when you get to some new areas
- Invisible walls in the middle of the path, passable walls that shouldn't be
- Almost no equipment and the economy is a mess
- I managed to skip to the final boss without doing some "mandatory" stuff near the end
- Sometimes you get no or almost no clue as to what to do next
- I did one side-quest near the end that brought me from lv 30-ish to lv 99, basically ruining the end game
- One of the worst, most unrewarding endings I've ever seen.

I could go on and on listing cons, but that should be enough. And all those positive reviews... they're either blind fans, or they have very, very, VERY low standards.
I have AoI 2 as well, and I think I'll try it someday, but, god, if you don't have it, don't buy it unless you just want the cards.

Edit: After playing AoI2 for about 3 hours, geez, it's abysmal! Don't bother with this series.
Read More

Posted: September 16
I am a sucker for old school RPGs. The plot seems to be well thought out, even a fine mix of humor built in. I like the characters and battle system. If there was a flaw it would be the mob lists. Dungeons consists solely of the same encounters over and over until you get to the boss/end. Other than that, I love it.
